clarifying some things here.

A child theme - inherits all of it’s code from the parent unless you provide a file with the same name in your child theme. In that situation your child theme’s file will override the parent.

As for CSS there are several ways you can load custom CSS using a child theme to add it where necessary is the most future-proof solution if you need it to apply to specific templates or your whole theme.

Cloning a theme creates a literal copy of the whole theme but with the caveat that if it’s a marketplace theme - you lose the updates from the theme provider. If you want to retain updates from the theme provider just like WordPress you’d want to use a child theme.

Regarding adding CSS, if you only need your CSS to apply to 1 page, you can add a css file through the page settings advanced options in the page editor.

Additionally an option though not the ideal solution - if you need the stylesheet to apply to your whole website, you can add stylesheets to apply site wide through website settings.

The ideal way for a developer though is using a child theme as that gives you the most control.
